article:
A limiting factor causes a population to decrease in size. A few limiting
factors are food, shelter, water, space. These are not all limited to the
condition of the species. Some factors may be increased or reduced based on
circumstances. An example of a limiting factor is sunlight in the rain forest,
where growth is limited to all plants in the under story unless more light
becomes available. This decreases plants photosynthesis.

A number of potential factors could influence a biological process, but
importantly only one is limiting at any one place and time. This recognition
that there is always a single limiting factor is vital in ecology; and the
concept has parallels in numerous other processes.

Some other limiting factors in biology are water availability, temperature,
shelter, or predation. See Liebig's Law.
